div.p: THE SPIGHTFUL SISTER. A New Comedy. Written by Abraham Bailey, of Lincolns-Inn, Gent.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Dring the Younger, at the White Lion next Chancery-Lane, in Fleet-Street, 1667.

EPistles and Prologues being for the most part skipt over without reading, I had thought to have silenc'd my Pen as to either of them both, had not the importunity of the Stationer (who was unwilling to have a blank page, but that the Buyer might have enough for his money) prevailed with me so far as to give thee this short account of it; That as it is a Play, so I made the writing thereof onely my Recreation, not my Study; done in few hours and youthful years, that may (rightly consider'd) excuse the Faults therein, which (if I am not partial) are not great, nor many; onely these few committed by the negligence or oversight of the Printer: I must desire thee either gently to pass over, or else with thy Pen to correct.

Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: I Say, It is not so good to be cheated as to Cheat: So I do.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Do's he mean honestly?

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: Hang honesty, he has put me to I-know-not-how-much trouble. I vow, so I do.
A-Deuce take him for a knave.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Patience Sir, he did not intend—

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: Intend a fool; I protest so I do, I don't know what to do, I'm so vext about it.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: He comes.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: How de y' Sir? Wel, what say you? de y' mark, I protest
So I do, you had almost hindred me of seeing
You; so you had, if you had not come as you
Did: Will you pay-in the Money, and have your Bond?

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: My fortunes bow to you.—

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: I can't abide this elegant Fortune,
Not I; My mony, My mony, Man?

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Let my Condition plead for me.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: That won't: the condition of the Bond is, to pay it
Double, (de se?) double, I vow.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Your Honour's Merciful.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Merciful me no more than I Merciful you:
For I vow (de se?) get it me quickly, or Il'e
Know why you won't: so I will as I live-law.
Go bid Berania come to me, do so.
Well, how now Berania, what say you to me about
Litus? I protest, I believe he looks like a rich Man.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: More tortures yet! The harmless dove pursu'd
By threatning death from the Jar-falcons Talons,
Avoyds that cruel touch, and lives secure;
My duty checks too great a scorn but Love.
Can utter stranger to his qualities,
Free me from Inquisitions, worse then Death?

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Well then, you won't ha' him? Il'e tell him the
Long and the short of the business, so I will.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Tis strange to see wealths power more then the strength
Of Vertue, stack't by Craesus his false fame;
Mony's Lord Paramount, and Riches sway
My Fathers fancy, for a prudent Soul
Content's a Paradice, as unknown to most,
As are the furthest Limits of Euphrates.
Every Sense turns Secretary, to record
His or my own hard Fortune, yielding's fatal;
I have set my Resolution, and I'le see
Myself Incloystred e're his wife Il'e bee.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Well, how stands the wind of your Daughter's Good liking?

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Why I protest-law it was so sharp North (so 〈◊〉
〈◊〉, that it had like to ha blown my Nose
Away, I vow, so soon as I mentioned you to her;
Law-ye.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Be plain.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Why, the Long and the short is, de se? she say's, she
Won't have you, I am in haste I vow, good b'y.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: To Fortune's Jiggs the vulgar sort apply
An arm'd resistance, whose weak affronts
Dare not consult with Passion, unless
It sings their requies sum: To love
Is to be resolute, our wealth's a blessing
To be contemn'd by none but those whose thoughts
Fly to a Pin-feather'd Philosophy,
And use a Microscope, mounted on wings
Of rare devotion to see if the World be any thing:
My blood thaw's silence at a womans scorn;
Stay till I come.

sp.speaker: 1. Foot-Boy.
sp.p: My Lord will have her sure, if Means can do it.

sp.speaker: 2. Foot-Boy.
sp.p: He's too well known, to be belov'd by her.

sp.speaker: 1. Foot-Boy.
sp.l: In his land her denial may walk so far,
Tell it's weary steps, and forget itself.

sp.speaker: 2. Foot-Boy.
sp.p: I don't know what they'l do.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Go deliver this Letter to Madam Berania,
The labour of a strict persute,
Is recompenc't by handling the Prize.
Delay, like Poppy, invites to a sleep,
That cutting news should be the hardlier felt.
Provide a bow for smiles: but if disdain;
I'le get by Force what fair Means can't obtain.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Your syllables make worse than banishment:
More captive to impiety, then the unwearied Passenger
Toth' fained mourning of a Crocodile
Whose jaws, while reeking in the bloud of those
His last allurements sung sad Dirge's to,
Seeks larger Preys.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: May duty teach my Sister.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: A Nobler lesson than Rebellion prompts to.
Recant your error, so your Reason may
A Prospect of all happiness seem clear
As day, whose Minute are seldom favour'd by
Such smiles of Chance, as those were proffer'd you:
Resolve amendment; to your changed mind
The Golden Sands of Factolus come flowing;
Imbrace Honour.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: By nourishing the hopes of Litus, whose soul,
As sad as Niobe's, takes pleasure
In throwing down the Gems that dwel in it.
His Birth ne'r taught him Courtship for a Maid
Below it self.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: His rashness, like a Warrant,
Seconds his malice: to these I am an Enemy,
Had he no more blasts of Morality.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: To call him rash is Passionate, Passionate witty,
An ornament to Youth.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Malicious too.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Hatred's a Puritan compair'd, and frowns
To see you learn your lesson but by halves,
Too openly bore down his friends at this.
Would keep the Scent, and were you a Man,
Turn bloud-hounds, ore-turn weapons 'til revenge
Had gi'n the Lye, to all that dare maintain
Him otherwise then a Fable, he sighs
Meekly for you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He's worse then Savage, that to get his will,
Won't Fawn and Flatter; but denyed still,
His expectation suddenly converts
His faigned Love to hatred and imparts
Envy to Force, till with his wile he gets
His own desire, by ‛ Proteus Changing fits.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: All fancies Suppositions worse, his wealth
It's so weighty, 'twould quickly surprize
The swelling of a crook-back't quality,
Nobles are a Pumice, hard enough to grinde
His errors into nothing.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Rich and Noble,
Be coverlids of vices wrong, 'tis pitty
Who's greatest fit to govern, he's not fit
To govern others, that cannot rule himself,
They should grow big together, Pliny never
Mockt Physick better. He comes, I'le not see him.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: To paint out to my self the warlick Trophies,
Due to a Conqueror, of all that's bad
And strong; the stoln hours
Of Leander and Hero, when the Hellespont
Was but a Kennel to him; argues their joys,
Pigmies Fiction short of truth: my Sense
Has made no Plaudit, 'til your Sister
Seem'd checking my hasty courtship, with a brow
Clear of Anger.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: A pleasant Landskip!

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: False.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: A Dream, may be.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Worse.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: My Industry may embalm your hopes.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: I come senseless here with equal passion,
Heaven or hell mop't to a Bul-begger;
I Tantalize my self, such a dul Agent
Deserves to see a foollish Messenger
Bring back his Letters, covered wich the mocks
Of a Chamber-maid. Harpes, true Harpes, come,
Why stay'st so long? ' Its past the time you promist.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: An't I within my time, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: No less
Then Ten pound, for an hours work: what say'st?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: Propose.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Trusty; ha'st forgot that Vertue?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: My Bonus Genius, I am ne'r without it.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Canst ' Fight?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: No matter: I can murder, may be, without it.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Pish you are wide o'th' mark,
We are about Venial sins.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: Nay that's the mark I'de aim at.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: A Lady, I'de ha'you and I steal from her Father.
Every night they walk at six a clock here:
Her Father's an old fool can't fight,
Be ready: But if we are caught, canst swear?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: If I can't swear, I can doe nothing.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Get a Coach ready at six a clock precisely,
Then meet me here.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Lord Lidorus, Lord Petus, attended.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: What Friar grac't his Order by a Miracle,
In Spelling you to a Platonick love?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Resolves after Deliberation make
A Circle; in whose Center, the best life
Lyes hid on puny spirits such as boast
They have the Summum Bonum when they tread
In an old Mark made by their Mistris Shoo;
I'le bestow pitty.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: To receiv't agen,
When tired with burdens of a way to Honour;
Your Motion's quick, your Hands gripe labour, Mind
Resolute to advancement, purchast by
A weary diligence: a Ladies lap
Inchants your purpose to a solitude,
That into sleep, sleep to a dream, whose language
Courts you to sweetness inconceiveable:
As Considerations of Eternity.
A Thousand presidents, bewail lost time, in your condition.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He's well can beware of others Harms,
Example don't excuse a Fault,
Love-sick's a great one.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Hold, a line of this subject.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Let's hear it.

lg.l: O Sacred! Sacred Love,
earths chiefest joys above!
That with thy nimble bow,
take'st pride to stick below
Thrice happy he whose Heart hath felt,
the quiver of thy Golden belt.
When Moping spirits Muse,
what pleasure here to chuse.
Then Love's great shrine draws nigh,
with enterprizes high,
To sway Mens hearts and wrap them Eeven,
to joyes divine, a taste of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Parturiunt Montes. To our business.
Letters Inform me of the neer approach of Death toth' Reverend
Old Man: already 'tas took up all but his breath-room:
Those Industrious hands that have so often acted his words,
When they moved Audients passions to Love,
To Hate, to Mirth, to Tragedy,
Have now nothing to do but second fervent Prayers for you and I.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: I'me promised news to day.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I expect some too.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: At six a clock let's meet here,
We'll impart the Novelty of each stop,
And drown the time with tears that speaks him dead.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'T may fall out not so. Starrs, and the best of Men,
Do rise to set, and set to rise agen.

div.stage: Enter Occus, Losana, Thele, Berania, Hacca, Hare, and Beucer.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Well, how now, Mr. Hare? well, de se? I don't know
I vow, Oh will you pay in the Money, law-ye?
And have the Bond?

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: You let others have it: upon that condition,
I told you of, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: Sir I doe, and I do not.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: How do you then?

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: Very well, but that's nothing: my Money, Man!

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: I'le provide it,

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Good-buy: come Daughters, it's almost time to walk,
As I live, so it is, i'th' Garden: so I doe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Will you bear us company?

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: My hours an't my own.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Well Beucer, you se (so do you,) that this Hare
Won't pay-in the Mony, so he won't,
I Vow now, de se, you may go if you will, I don't
Need your Witnes-manship.
Come Daughter I'l walk presently, as I live law-ye:
And tell you, you are a Fool! so I will, I vow, for not
Marrying the Gentle-man.

div.stage: Enter Harpes, and Litus, with a Beard.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I shan't be known, well Harpes art ' resolved?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.l: My horse needs nothing but a Silver spur,
To hasten it on in such an Ambuscado.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She's leight, my Boy, we'll carry her with ease.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.l: Leight! All the sex are so, Shee has been too leight
For you already, you may speak Probatum.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Stand in that corner you, but first provide
A Sword to fright the old Man, the young one's got
The sooner.
Honour's not repaid with Checks.
If her estate be it bladder's her Pride
I excell it; if her birth excell, that too.
These things well weighed, my brest's too generous;
To be submissive, and, at a Woman's scorn,
Turn Novice.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: A cold Iron!

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Hot enough to make him run, as Firebrands do
The Beasts of Greenland within that place:
I'm here. Let 'um walk a turn or two, we may
Take 'um at the more advantage.
Harpes, Coach waits.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Are you ready, Sir?

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: I'm ready to blow my fingers, they'r so cold I vow,
So I am.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Haste Petus to his Elegy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord, Lord Petus stayes to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Bid him come in, and bring hither a Table.

div.stage: Enter Petus, Boy sets down the Table, & exit

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: He's gone, those Ensigns of Honour;
Your proper due Succession ushers in.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: His Monuments.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Rich with the power of a holy Relique,
Read it.

div.stage: Harpes and Litus set on Berania.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Hark; the cry of some distrest Gentlewoman!

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: At the sight of a Frog.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Hark, hark, in earnest let's run.

div.stage: (They run and see her between them.) Occus crying.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Dishonourable Villains! what Commission?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Our fancy's to your cost.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: We'l try, provide.

div.stage: Occus creeps under the table, and peeps.
Enter Occus from under the Table.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: The Rogues! pittiful unvalourful Dogs! I was mad as
I live-law, to see what Cowards they were, I vow,
To set on us as we were walking: but I
Wisht 'um hang'd in heat of blood; as I'm here,
So I did: thank the Gentlemen, Daughter, that
Have so finely delivered you.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
To your protectors I'le be devout,
And beg for a reward due to your Vertue;
All the entreaties of a bended knee
Shall guard my Sacrifice till courteous Heavens
Know the deliverance of an innocent Maid.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Confirm we have serv'd you by excepting it,
The Gods make apprehensions of a Traytor,
Confound himself, his means, all dy'd with horrour,
Speaks daggers to his guilty soul, and saves
His enemy a triall.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: My life payes tribute to your valour.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: If it be valour, Madam, we no way
Can guess it's rising, but from the bright day
Of your own Beauties, which great Nature throws,
And duty ties to the hearts of all those
As profess honour.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Humble thanks your licent to my departure.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Your obliged Servants.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Well, Gentlemen, I protest, so I do, this is a
Great kindness; and I vow, I don't know how to
Make you amends, so I don't: but good by.
I would thank you a great deal longer, as I
Live-law (de se?) but I vow I am a going home.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Do'st know this pretty Gentlewoman, prithee?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Why d'ye ask?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Her Wit, Beauties, and Behaviour are excellent.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Surprized indeed.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Be impartial to a Corrector.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Maintain it who are most secure
From Love his torments, soonest do endure.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: What sudden passion, like damp news of death,
Conjures my blood about my heart grown weak?
Because I can't expound a petty riddle
Delivered her, what then? I'le ne're believe,
I alwayes dream'd till now I ha' been Garlick,
Destructive to Love's adamantick vertue;
Her very posture how it presents it self
Before my intellect, as a true prologue
To some future and stronger invasion.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Prefer the memory of those Gentlemen;
Doubtless, Madam, they were some that knew you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Not one thunderbolt to kill this monster?

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Trouble findes ease when open'd, Madam,
To my obedience here's, my life. Your counsel
Is further from my mouth than Mahometism.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: He in the beard had the voice of Litus.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Monstrous villany! Can so foul intents
Lie i'th pavement of so smooth disguise?
The world's deceitful, who by fair words,
Credit, performances just and honourable,
Finde one is empty, the other void,
Perfidious.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I wish all been't so.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: That all for one be blam'd, Heavens forbid!
Though foul pretences under fair he hid;
Yet mischief gathers mischief, and who thought
Others to catch, in his own net is caught.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Providence may pay him so.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Let my industry ease you of these sighs,
Your Sister's with him often.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Innocence is preserv'd by Angels.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Be it criminal, and take away my life,
To speak my Mistress Secrets; tell me, Madam,
What I ha' been I'le ever be,
In life a trust, to death fidelity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Inquire the names of the two Gentlemen
That rescu'd me, describe the blackest most.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: You love, I will dear Madam when I ha' done:
He begs admittance to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hush, here's my Sisters Maid, be intimate, enquire.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: What she knows is my own already.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Madam, your Sister prayes your company.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I'le go my self.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: Do'nt Litus often wait upon your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Yes, shee'd have her Sister marry him;
His treachery ha's burthen'd all mens ears.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: worse than a Rape.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Who told you?

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: I was by, and see it my self.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Since you know it, no longer I'le deny
Her private malice, his invet'racy

sp.speaker: Hacca;
sp.l: Shall be no more the cause of discontents,
To expectation happen cross events.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: IT's all as I tell you.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.p: Your Pilot taught you that trick.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: I lost my silver Hatband aboard.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.l: You thought she had been a prey conveighed thither;
By Cidnappers upon that built your hopes,
That Virginia would a nurst your Bastards:
Instead of writing your Masters Accounts,
Nothing was heard but, pray give Mistress Sarah
More Punch, white Bisket, Oyl to her Fish; her mother
Will oyl your Fish.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: By this hand I'de not love
A Wench as well as thou for more money
Than you got by Annoque-Tobacco last year.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.l: You love smoak too 'tis a sign, or else
You'd ne're a crept i'th' Stow.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: But say, Wilt marry her? I'le adde to the Summe.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.p: Marry, I may do so.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.p: I don't love Flie-blows tho, farewell.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: It's easie to do that with one finger
Can't be remedied: my business don't fadge.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Did you see Hacca?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: How long ha' you been here?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Mum.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Pray tell me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: The man's in a maze sure.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: I'me in a maze sure enough with your face.
That sure is a Screech-owl to my advancement;
I wish I had a Wife, to spoil this ugly business,
This Gentlewoman's better, my conscience
Is i'th' Spanish mode, I'le see to get her:
Her name's Thele; my Schoolmaster I remember
S'ed, the Beast Hyena had that in her
Would be witch a man to love: I think
This Maid ha's some Hyena in her too,
I have a Book at home s'es, Marriage is
Honourable, but it is good to be honourable.
I'le take another course, use this no more,
It's better love a Wife, than keep a Whore.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Imperial Madam, Could no lucky merit
Resist the charm of an insulting passion?
A foe as just as cruel, resents affronts
With rage, impetuous beyond proud Tarquin,
I'le do more penance than a Gally-Slave,
That spurns his thraldom with laborious strokes:
Eager to anticipate his destiny,
I'me guilty to expoliate my crime.
As your despiser strike my heart assunder,
But save the Love within it, carry it to her,
And tell my own words did it, may be then
One Tear may fall to glue it up agen.

div.stage: Enter Litus Covert from the Wood.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: A vow, as fatal to my purposes,
As his wisht Sword, whose glist'ring brandishings
Makes accents to his words, commands attention:
Must I be pillored to dishonour, stand
The moveless subject of both their hisses:
'Tis for Berania dye or cut through throngs
Of danger, were revenge i'th' same place,
Her favour should a grac't, surprize his chants,
E're they cleave air, and come unto her ear.
I speak of things above me, to his strength
My wounds set seal, may be he's innocent;
Then 'twould be base to intend a mischief, change
Thy fury into reason, may chance that may
Invent a safer and securer way.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What Bird has crost thy way? and drove you back
With Omens to our meeting, tell me prithee:
I'm Miserable of all lovers, that love
And dare not reveal it.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: Nothing but Sunshine to our intents, Madam
Why grieve you? To your smiles I'le bett my Honour,
He suffers more for you, than you for him.
I see his blood daunt in his face: as if
It were Eclipst, and strove to master Love.
His eyes were steddy, you paid it again;
Not without checks to those inamoring Lamps,
For taking so much liberty.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Recount your Progress, to me dissemble nothing.
Ha'st spok to him? if he be sworn already
To serve another Mistris, I'le but weep,
And sing her happiness, where signs shall keep
Time to my Song, and part each line from other.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: 'Tis no such matter Madam; let us make
This hour remarkable, by finding out
A way may ease us, and resolve our doubt:
I'le do it thus.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: I'le go a purpose, to ask if he took
The sword from him, that had the black beard on;
Pretending your misdeem is singly plac't:
And could by seeing the sword judge who it was
Before he answers: a dissembled qualm
Shall beg my excuse, for leaving him so quickly,
He comes my life for't, to resolve your self.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I like it, go, let providence bespeak
A crown for this imposture 't may deserve one.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: If Love won't, pray let Pitty, of your oths
And earnest promises, incite you to
A kinder satisfaction for my Honour.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: What, alwayes haunted with you as a Ghost?
I ha' found me a new Love: Seek you one too.
Admetus told me what would come of medling with Sluts:
I lost my Silver Hat-band aboard, following him about.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: Consider, how your self swore and protested,
You were enamoured, of my poor Beauty;
Let the remembrance of your former Love
Be a privation, to your present Hate.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: Why? rest contented, I tell you, if you had not
Been so free of your flesh, I should a loved you still:
And according to Plato, I may agen.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: Justly disdained Sarah, now thou reap'st;
The fruits of thy o're fond credulity.
How oft might I have been candidly intreated?
Had I not thrown away my self upon
The Charybdes of his flattery; which brings
Me to the Scilly of this extremity
To repair my esteem, by his enjoyment,
Or take revenge for his disloyalty.
Away! should I, under a nother's name
Disguised, seek to vindicate my self
Or reputation, a las I may dye,
I love him too well, use fair means, Il'e humbly
Go and complain to Mother, and seek her help.
To urge affection, Treason lets refrain,
What meekness can't? Malice will ne're obtain.

sp.speaker: Winifred.
sp.l: Oh! my Daughter! my Daughter! my Child! my
Chick! Where hast ' been my Love?
Come pretty Sarah, I have not seen you I
Know not when.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Man is but Mortal, his resolves more brittle
Than Ice a minute old: Certainty
Rests til 't'as breath, and fly's away agen
For one new reason, all faculties strike sail;
But sundry passions we are subject to,
Make Civil-war: then to the victor must
A pleasing object be presented. Love
Revels in's humours: What sad ditty is this?

lg.l: Help ease great Powers, Why do you thus prevent me,
And laughing takes a pride still to torment me?
My fears and sorrows sadly mourn within,
To see their cause from troubles still begin.
Then miserable I, how shall I bear it:
Languish for Love, and yet must not declare it.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.p: I fetch her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: 'Tis he
From moaning your condition, your own plaints
Besought me silence; let's confirm our friendship.
On your resolve to love none, experience
Has preacht a better lesson, then Meditation
Furnisht me with afore you sung.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.p: Madam, here's the Gentleman, here's both I think.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: While hot a wound's not felt, in the amazment
Your arms gave period to, I thought of nothing
But gratitude: since (all things quiet) Circumstances,
As Treason seldom goes unpunish't, offers
Me means of finding't out, the Sword, my Lords,
Discovers his Master's vilany if't be he,
Had either of you it from him.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: He run woo't in his hand (Madam) 'tis kept,
To cut his Conscience when he gazes on't.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Well, how now Daughter? I protest (so I do)
I wondred where you were, I vow, your servant, humble Sir,
Your servant, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Yours.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Father, to these Gentlemen we owe
Our rescue in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: I vow, I think, I thought so, pardon me Sirs, I
Did not know you, I vow, so I do, why we fought
Bravely, I protest law-you, I was never in a worse
Combat in my life, as I live-law, but we came
Well off (de see?)

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Heavens, be thanked.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Gentlemen, will you please to drink a cup of Wine?
I vow I'de have you come in, (so I would,) be merry
All danger's over now, de-see, I pray' come in do so.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: We'l follow your courtesie, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Ah! Sweet Thele, Mistris Thele love me.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: I wonder, you importune me so.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: Thou, sweet-sweet-sweet-sweet-sweet face,
Wo'd I had thee I'de give all the desks in my Bond.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: I must confess you are so charming, that
Your Rhetorick, like Orpheus his Harp, would make
Stones flye about your head.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: If you'l ha' me,
My Rhetorick shall make stones flye about your
Ah ah ah ah ah head too.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Why, you are fuddl'd, you are in a pickle

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Of Cucumbers, it's salt to see you want ha me! I'me sure.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Go sleep: till sober sober carriage, then,
And better manners learnt, come we agen.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Ah my dear Duck! where ha'st been my Love?
Come Dear, we'l go home and ha' a pot of ale, my Love:
Alack I'm undone! help, help, help, my Delight weeps:
Who ha's hurt my Love? I'le ta ' 'um away.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: If I, dear mother, have transgrest the Law
Of Nature, what I expect but Justice.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Tell me my Joy, I'le beat, kick, scratch, claw, bite 'm:
My Dear, who ha's hurt my Love?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Have patience Mother, and provide your car
To hear my loss, the story I'le declare,
And beg your pardon: my Lord Occus his man.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I am a'most mad, my Love.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Pray hear. Beucer coming aboard the Ship
Where I was then to take my leave of my Uncle,
Profest me Love; and with a thousand sighs
Mingled entreaties, soliced.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Come, come, come, go on quick, speak my Dear.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: My good will that Heavens know I thought
Was innocent and conjugal, his lasting
Importunities and promises
Of Marriage took my honour from me. I
O'recome by his deluding tongue, am forc't
To wail my hard fortune, and wailing so,
Augment my griefs, and they augment my woe,
Without the least hope of comfort.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Oh oh! I'm undone, I ha' lost my Daughters Virginity,
Virginity, I ha' lost my Daughters Virginity.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Pray Mother hear.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Oh! I ha' lost my Daughters Virginity.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Good Admetus be pleased to relate his leaving me,
Tears stop my utterance.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Tell on Love, tell on Duck; tell me Sir.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.l: After this the Knave dishonestly leaves your Daughter,
And I believe is in love with another.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Is this true Daughter, my Joy?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: True, Mother.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I'le claw the Rogue's Nose off.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: The entertainment was good.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Cruel Love! that takes his chief delight,
To use his fury, and display his spight;
Frowning he laughs, and strives to punish still
A Wretch with death, and yet denies to kill.
I love to see her, and her very eye,
As soon as seen, make me dissolve and dye.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Unless you'd shake me off, expel these words,
'T bewraies your folly.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I pray did you see Beucer the Rogue, the Villain? I'le
Claw him to pieces, the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: You want not the Lion's Kall or Herb Philocrassa,
As Naturalists name't, to touch her hand,
Perfume her chamber, or mingle in her drink:
She loves you well enough already: nothing
Disorders notes, and breaks your harmony,
But silence to a friend runs open-arm'd,
The sweetest message of all history.
I'le be your Spokes-man.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Miracle of honour!

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Promise to meet me here betwixt those Walls,
I'le sing your Lullaby, and borrow breath
From the wing'd words of your Berania.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: My life and fortune wait upon the news.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Attend my return.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Your Sister loves.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Any other than your self?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: To be disobedient.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: And perverse.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: More than all this.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: She sleights your counsel, mocks your Fathers threats,
And, worse, o're throws her modesty: that custom
Which bears out Ladies, to expect the prayers
Of servants kindled by a hot denial,
Is buried in her thoughts; she out-does shame.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: Be particular.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Among these Trees I heard her Lover mourn,
The giddy mixt words of a strucken Soul,
Desires Oratour for Berania.
He went, she came attended by her Maid,
'Twixt his complaints and her rash impudence,
Comparison is lost; she stretcht invention
For wayes to make him know she lov'd him,
Devises stratagems to see him, runs
The rest of punishments for violating
Her self, and friends to your serious thoughts
Contempts as plain as day; her wantonness
And toleration in't, it plows up duty,
Sows pride in'ts place; and, if suffer'd to grow,
Will o're-top your endeavours to reclaim her.
Your birth puts briars in your hand, why use them,
Blow down her Babel.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.l: 'Twas my Father's will
As well as mine, a mischief 'fore 'tis hatcht
Is bended; lightly grown benums those Joynts
That reach it's head: For desperate Maladies
Let's use severe purgations. Tyrants rule
By being smooth'd up in their Cruelty.
Then torments pay their tutors negligence,
Who nourish sucking Vices with a Flatter.
I'le break her or my self, let's set a time.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Do it when you please.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.l: Don't fail, till then I'le seem
Honey to both.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: My heart forbids me, and I'le never see
Her wed another that refused me.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.p: Hee's a fine Gentleman, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: His carriage puts me to a greater muse
Than Sphinx's Riddle; What do'st gather Hacca
From his motions?

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.p: I'm no Diviner, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: A Gentleman, Madam, whom I dare speak vertuous
In doing Justice, was surprized and taken;
He suffers hardship in his close Confinement,
And seeks deliverance; his courteous Keeper
Craves but your hand and word for his Release.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I know him not.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: A Stranger assaulted by a crew of Thieves
Already his masters, when past hopes of life,
Is succour'd by a noble Passenger,
Not without wounds to th' Victor, whose dumb signs
Seek help from him he rescu'd: if he can,
And won't contribute to the cure of t'other,
Ean't he ingrateful?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: In the highest degree.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: The Pris'ner is Lord Petus, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You astonish me.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Your Pris'ner.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: To your Graces and Beauties; 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I like your mirth, but change your subject.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Millions of sighs beg leave to kiss your hand,
Confirm your Judgement to the case I put;
His flames consume him, quench 'm with one word,
Let me haste to his Deliverance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Twould be too coy his Service to deny,
To grant it argues too much levity.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: 'Twould not be lightness to resolve a Grant,
'Tis for his Life, Madam, deny't you can't.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Love e're he seeks it, that's immodest, so,

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Mercy before modesty ought to go.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yea, where the time can dispence but of one,

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: It don't this kill that will revive alone.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Let's try both then, one with the other will
More welcome be, good is discern'd by ill.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: To afflict one so cast down wo'd be too rough,
'Tis sin to tread what's trodden down enough.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Time future may what present can't produce;
Then of this favour let him make good use.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: I'le carry his pardon.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: The Stars take care of you, Madam,
Here's a Present beyond expectation;
You sav'd your blushes i'th' conquest too.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Our inventions may sleep hereafter.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: How finely coy you were! I see Disguise
Is the Familiar of a Lady, Madam.
This verifies the Proverb:
Women like Shadows are, which if you shun,
They'l follow; but pursue 'm, away they'l run.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: Mistris, the emptiness of my belly may tell you
How sorry I am for my last offence.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Then you fast for your looseness

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: Of life you mean; I can sooner be without my
Ears than seeing you.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: You flatter.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Like a Magpie.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: You dissemble.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: This knocks down my ambition, if I do not wait
Upon you, that is to say, have your company; for
Sadness I am a second Melpomene.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: But not half so grave.

div.stage: Enter Occus and Winifred with a stick.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Oh you Rogue Beucer, 'tis he, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.p: Why I vow so I do, this is a disgrace.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Nay, hear woman, I vow I never see such a woman
I' my life, I protest so I do.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I ha' lost my Daughters Virginity, the Rascal had it
Aboard the Ship, and now leaves my Girle.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Speak softly, and I'le answer you.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Why I vow, why did you do so? you are a Knave;
De se, as I live-law, marry her, marry her.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Do, she's my onely Girle, then I'le love thee my Chuck.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Be patient, she's handsom I must needs confess.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why law-now he may marry her in time.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: If he don't, my Lord, I'le scratch the Rogue.

div.stage: Enter Berania, Hacca, Losana, and Thele.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Here's my Father, Sister.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: I Daughters I am here about an ugly business:
I vow I wish the Devil had it, so I do.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: Pray Sir tell it us.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I vow one thing comes before another, that I can't
Speak a word, I'm so vext, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: Pray Sir tell it us.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I will forsooth Mistris.
My Daughters Virginity! Beucer, the Rogue Beucer
Ha's lain with my Daughter, and sleights her.
How d' you Cozen, Beucer the Rogue ha's defil'd
My Daughters Virginity aboard a ship, and now ha's left her.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Ha's he so! (O Goodness!) Aunt be patient.
Is't possible? pray Aunt say nothing of it,
Till I give further order; seem to forget it.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I will indeed forsooth Cozen.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Beucer, how can you profess love to me,
And have abus'd my Cozen? It's well I know it;
May be I'le help it, Wisdom instruct me in't.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Well Daughters, de se, I'le leave you I vow.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.l: Sister, your strangeness troubles me; if Love
Take up your fancy, tell me, to your counsel
I'le be as faithful as your inward thoughts.
Your Looks speak Passion.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yours not Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: Truth needs no gloze, Lord Petus claims you his.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Who told you?

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.l: A Friend,
They know more than my self.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.l: Wan't Litus potent good enough for you?
Ha's too much pride bewitcht you? he s'es true,
You do insult, and more, if suffer'd, will.
It's good remedying new sprung mischief still:
'Tis my resolve e're you two married be,
I ha' vow'd a stop.

sp.speaker: Litus,
sp.p: A Tragedy.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Welcom Lidorus—.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Snatch that word agen,
Do not mistake the liveliness that sits
Upon my Face is to add to perswasion;
That you would bear the news of doubtfull things
With a stay'd Courage.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Some religious man
Be fo't to prepare me for a death
To th' world and all his vanities: within
A narrow Cloyster I'le hem in't my wishes;
And when the Bell rings to a rigid meeting,
Repent my earthly thoughts, and punish them
With hard mortifications: speak my doom,
Or point it rather, let some dying sign
Throw my misfortune in my face, that I
May hush up all in silence.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Take it then,
Stay'd courage lest you should be extasi'd
With joy, and make your succour your undoing,
Like those are a'most starv'd when they see meat,
Expire with greediness.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: What doubtful things
Should check my welcome to you.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Can'st believe
A man may be in Paradice e're he prayes for't?
Or hover amongst Angels e're he thinks it?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: As to his thoughts may be.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Then be so.
Upon my honour all she commands you,
Is to be faithful; such a glorious Flower
Ne're blossom'd in so short a time before:
Her words are full of sweetness, mild and fair,
Courteous as may be, free from fond allurements.
I beg'd your life, she grants it, visit her,
And find more than I tell you to be true.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Say but she's mild, and I'le out-dare worst fate,
And kind, there's ne're another word like that:
It lifts my fancy higher than the story of Elizium.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Take my faith to't, mild and kind too.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Sure the Sphears sing to beguile me;
Upon your memory ten thousand thanks
Shall dwell: I'le publish how much friendship is
In Lisborn, in your self with such an accent,
'T shall more an imitation till the world,
Know to be honourable.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Your pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Well, how d'ye Gentlemen? d'e see, Sir, I am come
About a business of very great exigence as I
Live-law, so I am I vow the case is thus Law-you;
I heard you were in Love with my Daughter,
(D'e-see) and I vow she might a had a Lord
With a great Estate, (d'e-see) but as I live-law
I am so much a friend to Valour, I vow, that if
You have a good Estate, look you, Sir, I had as
Live you should have her (d'e-see) as any body else.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p:
He possesses the Revenues of a noble and industrious
Family, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Look you, Sir, I an't for complementical words; but here
Stands the case, if my man Beucer s'es you are
A pretty Gentleman (d'e s'e) as to Estate, as I live-law
I'le present to my Daughters marrying you I vow, so
I will with all my heart: Can a man say more
For his heart-blood, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You are all-obliging, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Why every body se's so, as I live-law: Come smoak
A Pipe of Tobacco at my house, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We attend you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: Dear Mistris I sigh till I am as hoarse as a
Parrot, and cry every day, I beseech you love me.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: If I thought you were in earnest, I'de let loose
The reins of love, it's hard to keep 'um in;
You are so bewitching.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: To my fovour, my face you mean:
If I ben't in earnest, I wish the hands of a
Pick-pocket may deprive me of my Looking-glass,
Before I see home.

div.stage: Pulls out a glass and looks in't.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: A deep curse, is it so precious?

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: A representitive of the external faculties of the
Face; or rather to talk elegantly: The lively object
Of Beauty or deformity; In which we view as it were
The heart through the eyes.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: These are high words indeed,
To be no longer woo'd, I love: and think
The day too long till wee are Married.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: I am mad with joy! Your goodness! Your goodness!

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Ben't carried away with every beauty,
And leave me; seeing I have been so free:
And opened my self to you, I could not help it;
Every sight of you made my stomack dance.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Will you grant one favour, sweet Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: In Modesty, what is't?

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Cool me a little Mistriss, it's my modesty makes Me mince it so.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Are you hot then?

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: Oh! Beyond the Superlitive degree far, alas, that is to say,
Otherwise tormented, you don't know how I burn!

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: You an't burnt yet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: But scorcht very much, adde that favour to the rest.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: My Service is due to you as my Husband, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: Give me leave to satisfie my self with you now,
And then, I shall dye without it, sweet Love.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'le obey your will vertuously inclin'd, Sir, but
I don't know what you mean.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Onely your company.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Henceforth command it.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: And the sight of Alablaster Legs, Mistris.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Away, Sir, that must crown our Marriage;
Rejoyce in this your sincerity made you the
First in my favour.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: I do indeed, this Verse of my own making tells you
So; for I had a good sign that you would
Love me: A Raven cried, Marry, Marry, at my
Chamber-window afore-day;
Now I have all, what else can I implore?
I ha' got my Love, and I desire no more.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: A very good Verse, we call it a Heroick, it ha's
Just ten feet, which is the Orthodox Rule
Of our Modern Poets.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The Fool, or rather Knave, thinks I am enamour'd;
I am so but to see my Cozen vindicated:
Heavens have heard my prayers, and smile down
A perfect grant to our own intents;
He sleeps in's pranks securely, little dreaming
That I am privy to his waggery.
How men speak double to ensnare our Sex
With gilded words, when all their purposes
Are more remote than East from West, I wish
I could but speak with her: Boy, you boy.
Go to Sarah Moren, and tell her I stay to
Speak with her.
Poor Maid, how she builds Castles in the Air,
And dreams of peace if he'd love her again:
Such is the thoughts of pleasure after pain.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Here, here Cozen, here's my Daughter, my Duck;
I came running in such haste, that I sweat
Intollerably.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Dear Cozen, I threw away sadness at your message,
Thinking it might have good news in it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I sent to renew my former charge that you
Would carry all things close and hush, and you,
Aunt Winifred.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I forsooth.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Be not so mad and furious
With Beucer, 'tmay contribute to your good.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I forsooth: I will indeed forsooth.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: My Mistris expects me. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Now Daughter, this is brave i'faith! this is gallant!
Hie Boyes! my Daughter, my Duck.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Let things be carried on in course, I ha' found
Fortune so fickle, that I can't repose
Trust to a benefit before I se't.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Well, my Dear, I'le do so too my Joy, so I will my Love.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: 'Tis possible to see good dayes once more,
Till then submit to that mishap it may be,
To others common in this world we see,
Nothing that's constant but inconstancy.
Not to remedy, yet to grutch is vain;
Use patience where we can't redress our pain:
The darkest nights bright morning still ensue,
After grief joy.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: It may be so with you.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: You Tom, this way mon.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: I saw their faces, they were like a Queen for gallantry.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You make a fool of one, so you do.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: I tell you you lie.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Then they'd be here afore now.

sp.speaker: Recorders:
sp.l: A Scene discovering Petus sleeping in a Field, four
Nymphs lay their hands on him, and sing.

sp.speaker: 1. Nym.
sp.l: I freely here thy pleasure: pronounce in Joys rich Banket;
O happy thee, whose eyes shall see: such bliss great love be thanked.

sp.speaker: 2. Nym.
sp.l: Your prayers are accepted: her heart doth well affect thee;
Venus affirms, her Son from harms: of envy shall protect thee.

sp.speaker: 3. Nym.
sp.l: My coming warns thee, Petus, of disasters,
Which with a hare thy head hang quivering over;
The Gods agree, no remedy
Shall save thy mirth, O harmless Lover.
By Fate ordain'd, e're thou wert nam'd,
A sudden hate thy Love shall cover.

sp.speaker: 4. Nym.
sp.l: Then rest contented, till the time's expired;
This past, your Joyes shall once again renew,
Thy fury will, lead thee to ill,
Of fight, and almost murther too:
Before the space of many dayes,
What we predict, you'l find it true.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Apollo's will's obey'd, let us address
Our Nymphly posture to the Wilderness.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.l: You Rogue you came too late; here was the
Rarest singing that e're you saw.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Rare! all mirth I brave Maids! I believe they were Spirits.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: You kiss my— Fool, they were Women.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: So they were, we see 'um go you way mon.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: They sung, and did so fashion.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: I can tell best, they sung so.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: What, what Gentleman's this?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: U●snigs, look here you, here's a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: Law-ya-now, you must pay ten groats for Swearing.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: What, in jeast you Puppy.

sp.speaker: First and second.
sp.p: He's no more Puppy than your self.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.l: Who s'es he is? remember this
When you come in our ground.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: There you may stay for me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Coward, a Coward, ah ha, aha.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: What Vision dare controul my quiet? Now
I'm Berania's I'le meet the shapes of night,
And jear their threat'nings, gaze on busie Spirits,
That would tempt men to dread their hellish Rhimes,
A power garrisons me from the mumblings
Of huge Succubusses, whose weighty load
Presses mens folly, makes a spill, and then
Turns to a Prophesie as false as may be.
Till now I fear'd to have the idle actions
Of a disturb'd brain, lest it had figur'd out
Some omen to my aim; but since she's mine,
Im not deluded with the lovely shape
Of fallest Nymphs that bless me in a Tune,
Nor pant a'th' curses of the two last Sisters.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What makes you look so sad, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Apparitions.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: They say I shall be a murtherer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Some that do not know, Madam, what strength I fetch from every word you speak to tear 'um.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Tell me the business.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Sleeping on this Bank,
Viewing your Idea deriv'd from my last thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Mine!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: When it is not yours, let it be deaths.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A shape too grim, my Lord; but pray tell on.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A couple of Maids, I like't them pretty well,
Assur'd me of my Heven, your self, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: No Heven.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I'de lose ten thousand lives for't.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Angels
Ordain you for a better.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Two came after.
Put clouds upon my hopes, and strove to vail 'um
With darts of envy, as thick as showers of hail.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Shine clearer by contemning fooleries.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I'le change them to ambition, that you
Instruct me to't, and speak what's in my minde,
A dream, it happens, by contraries this ha's;
'Twas trouble, till now this pleasant Meadows could not
Be sweet by the presence of Berania,
Nor I blest with such an encounter.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Dreams are but fancies, and who grieve or joy
At their portendment, dread and fear a toy.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Mishap o' Beucer for me, as I live-law he's an arrant
Knave, I vow; well, how d'ye my Lord? we come I vow to
See what you'l do about Marriage: I protest, so I
Do, d'ye love her still? I vow I ask because I don't
See you prate and talk, and hug her.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: To answer your demands is not—

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: To speak, we know your mind, an imprecation
Tail'd with a sigh, and silence is enough
To your favour, Madam, this man owes—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Inquiry how you pleaded for him.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.p: A Lawyer are you?

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: What's your Fee, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: But to kiss your hand;
Then I'le confine your angry brow to limits,
Your servants dye else, take a President.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: A Gipsie can't speak more, know things aforehand.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: I'le work that wonder, Madam, he confirms; Points to Petus. I ha' studied Phisnomy, told him his fortune.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What was that?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: His imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: To you?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: He'd sooner speak a line without a vowel,
Than leave abusing, those were Ladies Servants.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: It's punisht with a great deal of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.p: D'ye talk of trouble and sorrow already, (d'e-see?)

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: She speaks backwards, Sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Why, I vow that's the way to raise the devil, they
Say to speak backwards, so they do, don't, don't I pray.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No Sir, the Devil is raised by a Planetae impositione Retrogressa, as they call it.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: What's that? what is it like?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Why I vow, it's like to fright me out of my wits,
So it is, to hear you talk so barbastically of
Old-Nick, as I live-law.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: Language will be cheap, my Father farms it.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.p: Come, come prithee.

div.stage: Enter Hare, and three other Comrades.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Troth I am vext at the old Fool Occus, he ha's
Got a Pond of me for almost two hundred Pounds,
And no Witness but my Hand and Seal, (I would I had it)
And the Dorerd keeps such a quarter to have in
His money, that I can't rest for him, and to
Disbarst so much I can't neither: He's an old doting
Fool as ever I see.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.l: Why don't you make one of him, and get your
Bond then?

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: May-be he's a cunning Fool.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: I rather think so.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Here stands the business, I borrowed this money to
Build two or three small Houses; afterwards I morgag'd them,
And spent the money, and now this old Lord Fool
Would have me pay it.—

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.l: We can tell your meaning, you would put a trick
Upon him, and get the Bond without money.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Why faith I would and I know companions you
Are very ready in such businesses, you don't vvant
Wit; if you do't, I'le give you forty Pounds betvveen you.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.l: I am afraid it vvould be difficult to obtain, by
Reason his Man Beucer ha's the keeping of it; vve
Must do it by a vveild.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.l: For forty Pounds vve'l venture a broken Pate.
A trick, a trick.
Hannibal oft by policy ha's got
The Fort, his military strength could not.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: My true hearts be stout, I'le vvarrant vve do the deed.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Mr. Hare, I vow I believe you'll put me to trouble, to get my own money, so I do: I wonder you'll be so dishonest, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Have patience my Lord, I am here with three men that owe me mony, to pay in yours, if I can get it: they promise to do their best for me.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Best and worst, all's one to me: if you pay it in, d'ye see? you'll have your bond, and be out of harms way, so you will.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Why I tell you Sir, stay but till these men tell me what they'll do, and I'll have my bond.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why law you, because you are my friend I'll stay so long, so I will; but I vow, no longer, so I won't.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: 'Twas well you said we owed you mony; a good conceit.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: You hear him say he'll be delayed no longer, it will be worth our time, prethy gentlemen lets plot quickly; the reward as soon as the work's perform'd.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.l: You speak nobly, lets lay our heads together
To get the Paper, let our Genius tend,
And if we loose our labour there's an end.
sp.stage: Walk about a turn or two.
sp.p: Look here Sirs, I conceive this will be the best way, one of us shall go and tell Occus that he believes Hare is in a very poor condition; and that he believes Occus will loose his mony, if he don't look after him, but shall disswade him from arresting him, for fear that undoes him, &c. Then if he requires counsel in this case, he shall tell him, that he knows a cunning man, to whom if he goes with his bond, he's sure he can give him good advice.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Well said, by this hand thou hast a politick pate of thy own.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p:
Then I'm sure he'll go, for the old fool will ask of the Devil before he'll loose his mony: then one of you shall be the Conjurer: when he comes, dont ask to see the bond, lest it beget suspition; for Beucer has taught him not to trust his Father with such things: but make a Circle. You Mr. Hare shall be drest like a Devil: strange words we must use (but my life for't) rather
then he'll be torn to pieces, he throws down the bond; if so, take it up and keep it.
Hare shall be the Devil; you the Conjurer (to the second;) and I'll be his perswader.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Go attire your self (to Hare:) And you Mr. Conjurer be ready at a call.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: I will, I warrant you: do you stand and see private (to the first man,) I'll to perswade him.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.l: I shall get my part of Forty pounds for seeing
A trick; I'd be hired so always; it's good.
Mony, and pleasure too, 's a double gain:
I'll have the cole, and they may share the pain.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: I came a purpose, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Well Sir, what d'ye say?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: My Lord, love to you bids me tell you of a thing that may something concern you.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: What is't? what is't, d'ye see?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Sir, I hear Mr. Hare oweth you nigh two hundred pounds; he is in a very poor condition, and I believe, except you get it of him very suddenly, you will loose it, for he is down the winde.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why I vow, so I do, I'll arrest him, so I will, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: No, Sir, then he's an undone man, you'll ne'er get it so.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why, what would you ha'me do, d'ye see?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Here liveth a cunning man hard by, that is able to resolve you in all such points, how you shall get your mony, for a small piece.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Prethy tell me where he lives, I protest I'll go to him, I vow, so I will.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Stay, my Lord, I'll go fetch him, he lives at next door.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p:
Why, I vow, I think I was wrapt in my Mothers smock,
so I do, every body loves me so, so they do, I vow, to tell me how to get my money, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: This is he, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why, Sir, after humble commendations, I vow, there is a man, his man is Mr. Hare, as I'm here, a duce take him for a knave, oweth me almost two hundred pounds, and he won't pay me, I vow: I came to ask your counsel, so I do, for a small piece, d'ye see?

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Have you brought your bond, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: No, Sir, but I'll fetch it, d'ye see?

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Now for my skill.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Here it is, d'ye see?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: I have business, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.l: Well, will you stand still?
I, I, I, I, I, vow.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Your mony comes, my Lord, all to you, I'll warrant you, when we have made a Scheme; Earth and Saturn, you'll have it.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: My Lord, you will stand still be sure.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Shall I ha' my mony then?

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: No fear: hold up your bond in your right hand.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: I, I will hold it as fast as you will, I vow.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.l: Hy surge tu grande nebulo.
Iterum per nomen Poldavi surge.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Satan I defie thee, Satan I defie thee, d'ye see?
O I'll ha'no mony, I'll ha'no mony.

div.stage: Conjurer goes behind Occus and holds him.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Throw down the bond, or we shall be torn.

div.stage: Occus goes to throw it down twice or thrice, and pulls back.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: I'th' Red Sea for ever, i'th' Red Sea lay him.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Down with it, or you dye.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: O good, O good.

div.stage: Throws down the bond, and runs away.
Devil takes it up, unvails his face.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: Here 'tis, our will's obtain'd, our skill is shown,
The deed is done, and now the bond's my own:
Wit plays the critick, Policie keeps school,
I've got my wish, and Devil take the fool.

div.head: ACT. IV.
SCEN. 1.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: DIsconsolate old man under an Aspect
Shewing afflictions, were thy Infant-griefs
Conceived: Oh my Son Litus, is he dead?
Gray-hairs repose your sorrow in the Grave;
Oblivious of all future happiness;
Is he devoured? Monstrous cruelty!
Barbarism in wilde Beasts; could you not content
Your hungry stomacks, with the woful ruines
Of my deceased life, so often walking
Through dismal Alleys of your woody territories?
But you must chaw the Branch of all our Race.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Be not immoderate, my Lord, in sorrow;
May be some nimble Buck, while he was hunting,
Was trac'd to death by his toilsome pursuit;
Or else so far, some honest passer by
Must guide his looks to homeward: thousand chances
Hinder intents of coming back; and yet
When he returns, makes mirth to think upon't.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: No, he's lost.
Pray young Gentlewoman, do you hear report of Lord Litus?

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: Do I dream? or is his Villany before me? I'm terrified at's thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: How dar'st O base woman
Stain my Sons honour with the name of Villain?
Unless your words be reasonable, I'll make
My aged hands the tragick instruments
Of your untimely murther.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: Hold, my Lord, I have cause enough to speak it.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Out with't quickly.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: If he's your Son, Sir, understand he lately
Fained to sigh for my Mistriss Berania;
But she knowing his rashness, would not suffer
Him see, much less to confer with her: At which,
I weep to name it, he gave so much scope
To his vile passion, that he hir'd a Ruffin,
Help'd by himself, to force her from the Garden,
As she was walking with her Father and me:
She had perish'd, had not two young Gentlemen
Rescu'd her fainting soul; they kill'd his Ruffin,
Drove him away, my Lord; and since that time
Shame has conceal'd him.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Swear that this is true.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: By all my love to truth.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: Now farewel comfort,
Long since I have predicted some disastrous
And gloomy accident to follow his
High-minded stubbornness; Oh me, oh me!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A chair, a chair, my Lord faints.

div.stage: Enter Servant with a chair: he sits in't.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: My sons departure, tells me I must have
A doleful life, or else a doleful grave.
Fear ne'r to see him more, affrights me so,
It makes me loth to stay, and loth to go;
Lest he should live still, then if I expire,
'Twould kill his joy, and kill my own desire.
I'll tarry, perchance Heavens so kinde may be,
To revive my Son, and so to revive me.
By his return, if not, I'll yeild my breath,
First due to sorrow, and next due to death.
But why cheer I so? if he liv'd, ah then,
He'd send me news by word, or news by pen,
To ease my fears, or else expel my grief
By a quick burial, or a quick relief.
He's gone, I forgive you, now suffer me
To slide from this vale of extremity.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: My Lord, I've here one lately see your son i'th' wood hereby.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Away, kill me no more.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: What news, my Lord, has taught your eyes to weep?
Shed one tear more, and let that be bestowed,
For not accepting crosses as you should:
The change of all things here puts you in minde,
You're tossed like a Ball between the Rackets;
Shew your self Master of your passions; use 'um
As a wise Angler, play 'um all to death.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: My son is buried, but where I know not.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Since this days dawning, Sir, his son was seen
Alive and well in these adjacent Woods.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Won't all perswade a change, my Lord? believe it,
Breath while there's hopes, the truth is quickly known.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: How I pray?

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: If he's there, you have waies enough
For his recovery: beseech the King
His Forests may be search'd, and every place
Suspected, enter'd by his Commission:
The Seal makes people double diligent;
Let your reward provoke them to industry.

sp.speaker: Lonus
sp.p: I'll go and beg that favour of the King.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Poor man, how sad he is!
Joy to you Mistriss,
Make much of your Servant Beucer.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Is he mine?
Steward, count out a hundred Dollers for her,
Your news deserves it; till now, I could not trust
So fair a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: 'Tis so, never mock.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Forget to part the Cash, add ten times more,
It's seconded; the Guinian Neger never
Humm'd for his passage more to serve a Master,
Then I at this; may it be credited?

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: As what you see.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: The business Amorous
Takes up the thoughts, awakes and conveys them
To skreeks of slumber; as the matter is,
A pill eant half so pleasant; this has wash'd
Disturbance down: I can freely inquire
The love and progress of Berania.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Dissemble what you know, all is providing;
We wish his voice be clear, bids 'um good morrow
After the Musick of the Marriage-night.
My Mistriss airs out sweetest expectation
To drive the time away.
Occus is free to't, no impediment
Stains blew proceedings, but Lord Petus Father,
Who I don't know his reason, keeps at distance,
But 'twill away, it has been motion'd twice.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Patience to hearing's the first sign of grant:
He's faint, whose Fathers first repulse doth dant.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Vile, damn'd, rotten, pockie, ugly, devilish Dogs, I vow, they have got my mony and my bond, so they have; a Devil on 'um, I'll see the Devil Hang'd, as I live, law so I will, before I'll go to him again, for a Rogue as he is, I vow, to come to cheat so, as I'm here: I believe the Witches sent him: it's a damn'd thing to be a Conjurer.

div.stage: Enter King, Guard, Chancellor and Lonus.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: May't please your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Rise up, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: To grant me one Petition 't may put off
The sorrows that do over-whelm my heart,
For my sons loss.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Name it, be confident,
Your former Services lye fresh within me,
I'll do more then you ask.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: Humble thanks, Sir,
Betwixt this mornings fits of fate, when scarce
I could wish any thing but to end my life,
A beam warm'd me a little; and thus it was,
My son was seen alive; grant me so much,
All places may be searched with your order:
His golden mouth that tells me tidings of him,
Shall be inrich'd with a reward that's fit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why went he away?

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: I know not, but being out,
Some private grief is pleased with wandring,
And keep him there, if he's alive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I grant it,
Give whom my Lord appoints a large Commission,
To examine what's suspected; wish you tydings.

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.p: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Heavens bless your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Your worship, your honour, Majesty, King, King, the Devil has got my bond, so he has, I vow, I pray give it me agen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The Devil your bond, my Lord? I can't help that.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: So, so, this is very brave, the King can grant other things, so he can, I vow; but he won't grant me, so he wont, I shall be plagued still; a Devil 'um all for me, that mony would a bought me and my daughter new clothes to the Wedding, so it would, I vow; he had a confoundable great pair of horns, so he had.

div.stage: Enter Hare and the three Men.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Now our business fadg'd gallantly, it did.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: I, thank me.

sp.speaker: 3 Man.
sp.p: I got him here with a flea in his ear, to you Mr. Conjurer with your figures.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: Your figures got the bond.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.l: Old Occus thought we Saints had been,
He see us stand so civil;
Till I took him by the shoulder,
And thrust him to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Now you have your bond, let's go and have our mony.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: 'Tis due.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: My Lord Lonus sayes I shall have mony enough, if I finde him.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You? I'll finde him first, or I'll look as Nunkle Morris does the Hedges for a Hare, faith.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Swaukers, we'll all go, go whoop and hollow, till we make him see, if he be to be seen, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: You Owls, I'll make him come with a sussorarah, as the Gentle-folk say.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: If I finde him, I'll drink Sack with all the mony.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You drink Sack? you drink a— won't you?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Out on such an unmannerly bastard to say— you're a great booby.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: Hie to our work, before George.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Tell me some reason, Sir, 'tis easie for you
To contradict my remedy, because
You have forgot its torments; yeild to it,
Requite my duty with a Fathers grant:
Did you but feel the flames I do, your own
Tortures would kneel for a whole Sea to quench 'um.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Check your pretended fancy; to my care
Commit your self, I'll chuse a match shall please you:
Our Countries wide, within the circle on't
I'll fetch a beauty shall deface your Mistriss,
And bring you to your right minde.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Give consent
I marry her, or else command my grave;
One of them two must end my love or life.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: In sons obedience best besuits the minde
To Fathers precepts, as the Clouds by winde.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Yea, where obedience grees with good, 'tis so:
But 'tis not good to kill me; pitty show.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: I will in giving what my self affects.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: To please it self, Love others still neglects.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: Why Love approaching mischief cannot see.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: If that betyde, lay all your blames on me.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: 'Tis vain to move what's fixt: Heavens bless your choice,
That in your joys, we both may like rejoyce;
And not to strive against the stream, I here
Approve your love shown to your lovely deer.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Tell Berania, I am happy, sister;
Heavens shrowd from ills: Lidorus now descend—

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Maskers, or what?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Undisguis'd, I'll shew
Them all the way to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Why must we leave you?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Understand me, Lady, 'tis so nigh,
I'll look at it as the wise Elephant
Adores the Moon, and use variety
Of contemplation to express my Jubil.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Forget to sigh then.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: I may use a few that 'tis no neerer.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: I'll go carry her word,
'T would be too harsh tho: won't your patience, Sir,
Make earthquakes till its spent?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Now what are Ladies?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Forgive, my Lord, han't I had punishment?
If not, I'll leave the seat of Cherubins
And be your Vassal; 'fraid to speak, I'll wait
the slowest motion of your hand or eye
That calls me to't again: consult definers
Of Angels or of women; let 'um ring
With words of rapture above all the flourishes
Have been invented since the time of Rome:
I'll swear they say true, when they call 'um gods.
If this won't do, perswade some gentle Beauty
To stick me for a year; and all that while
I'll cry its just, and with my latest breath,
Damn my condition, 'fore I was converted.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: You make us think you worship every thing a Lady has laid hands on.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: I, and cringe
At a white Peticote a mile from him;
Be real, and under that consideration,
You'll finde a new world all made of delight.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: There's other things between.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: How now, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Else every one would make discovery.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Women and truth are best, when naked, ha'
The sweetness of imagination, when
Their lovely blushes in a pretty face
Are fancied, telling us of all our sins.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Or but one touch of their hands charm with pleasure:
Refiners are not half so jocund, Sir,
To see gold drops fall thick as Rain from Ore
That promist little.—

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: As I, my Lord, have been
About your age to dwell on the melting lips
Of those sweet Females.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Excellent, I faith, it posts to him, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: Nothing more welcome,
I have often wish'd to see my Sister muse;
A reverend Priest would joyn 'um both together.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: What undiscerned mischief dare lurk private?
The assenting trumpets of our holy Temples,
Confound all Treason; her one presence has
Power to kill the infection of an Adder
That leaps cross their can did intentions.

sp.speaker: Losan.
sp.l: None can be sure of futures; every point
Of time's defended from black Maladies
By something pious, or the influence
Of prosperous sighs.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Where both are pure as they,
I'll prophesie the eights of Harmony.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Curst not to credit you.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Your bashfulness
Kept you at distance, like a well-bred Masty,
Will see a shoulder of Mutton in a Dish,
And Perish ere he'll taste it. 'Twas me Madam
Beat the Alarm.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Noble Centinel,
To acknowledge it, I'll wait upon your safety,
And beg for watch-nights to attend your person.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Losana and Thele.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: Go for Litus: Thele stay you there,
Hell be almost angry I tarry so long.
To kill, or wound, or poyson, some of these
Shall open to the right or left: I can't
I can't, nor won't bear it, see my own self
Spit upon, while my younger flattering imp
Is always pray'd for and admired? away,
Let me be melted into nothing, if
I don't cure this ere I am two Suns older:
Stab me if I don't convert my promise
To performance. My Lord, their visits tire
The day: Cabinets full of letters stand
For gold to stare on, every breath brings message
Of new devoyrs, and returns deep loden
With Lovers whimsies: to your last discourse
I have paid reverence, 'twas right and true:
The hodge-podge words of her phantastick pate
Serve for good morrow to me: all their studies
Are for others to conjure one another,
In changing hearts: catalogues of their flouts
Swell when I'm amongst 'um; every moment
I ha'been urgent in perswasions to her,
She has scorn'd 'um.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Troth Madam, I wondred you
So long together could forget your birth:
Two gallant spirits, their continual practice
Strikes deeper then a Chinian Dart: You know
The unfit receiving she has of your counsel,
To all but who their cogging words and looks
Buy respect of; your Nobler minde is plain,
Kill bad examples; famous for a Pattern:
Shew their dull Genius the way to mend;
Correction's studied quickly, though I must
Confess revenge is hungry at their carriage,
I thought to come ere now.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: Take this prevention, shortly I intend
To put in practice arms that shall divide 'um:
It's time enough, the more intire they,
One bullet takes two bodies glew'd together.
D'ye think I can forget their outrages?
Sooner my name and Country; I'll bear both
Fair looks till then.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: My Father, I'm inform'd,
Has ordered for my search; I'll sooner dye
Then be discovered 'fore we have ended this.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: I'll flee to 't.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: If you don't, and quickly too,
I'll be contriver and Executioner:
She can't help it, may be, but my oath
Tears out the heart of one, if not of both.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: I have defer'd so long, dear Cosen,
In expectation of your promist help,
That I can't hide it longer; my shame begins
To increase: I fear without your sudden counsel,
I shall be forc'd to give the world an Infant:
I blush to think on't.

sp.speaker: Winifred.
sp.p: Don't do so, my Joy.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.p: Heal my distemper, use time while you have it.

sp.speaker: Winifred.
sp.p: I do, do my sweet Nephew, my love: my Daughter's with Childe for sooth.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Be diligent, ben't absent, shortly I'll send,
Till then I'll pray for good success.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: Heavens grant it,
My Cause is just; what rockie heart can hear
My sad complaints, and not relieve me? Wonders
Have brought content to th' harmless; let some vision
Threaten his disloyalty; and then beseech
Him view the curses ready to fall on him,
For taking holy things to witness how
Clear his thoughts were from this impiety.
Man's not impenetrable, can't a sin
Be frighted into goodness? sure it may:
Skies send I live to see that happy day.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Witness impartial ordinances how
I loath the falshood of a perjured lover:
Nature commands me to do justice, and
It's in my power; she admires him still.
Help me some shining Spirit to consult
Your own affairs, and reap the glory on't.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Dear Mistriss, I have seen a thousand doomsdays since you said I pleased you; one word now makes me lighter hearted then a feather; in sober sadness I shall be seen no more, if I dye for love: My tears run faster then Greyhounds for you: a good simile is the chiefest part of Language: I've read over the Academy of Complements, and pick'd out the best rhetorick to wo you; a Parson may Marry us: be attracted, be attracted.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: The eagerness I have of Marrying you,
Makes Moons seem twelve-months, every minute hours:
But for my friends good will, I had long ere now
Seal'd to our Wedding.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: You are so wise, Mistriss, that I should be worse then a Fanatick, to wish any thing till you say the word.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: These are expressions fit for strangers, Sir,
Not her that duty tyes to you, cease 'um pray.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p:
The best quality of a Sutor, is to be well spoken, and pronounce every word with an emphasis; and I thank my Stars, I have both as sure as a dye; and if I live, will delight your ears with the
high-flown words of Romances: Amadis de Gaule, and Palmorin de Oliva, shall be my every days discourse.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: High properties.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: And I'll delight your ears with songs of my own making.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Would you not have me coy?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: 'T would kill me twenty times.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Provide a Priest, we'll invite nobody.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Am I above or no? methinks I turn round, and see a hundred nooks, and a bag of gold in every one; so high and mighty is my rapture: when, Angel, when?

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Be Lord o'th' time your self, when you'll appoint it,
I have chang'd my condition already:
What a tode am I (to speak passionately?)

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: I bought a Token of my love, and forgot to give it you.

div.stage: Gives her a stomacher of Ribonds, and a Love-hood.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: You put your self to charge, I humbly thank you;
These shall be my Wedding-Furniture.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Every particle of 'um, I bought them for the same purpose; to be privately and suddenly Married, are the symptoms of a fiery and Elegant Lover, you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: You have forc'd my will, meet me at S. Thomas Church,
Ere half an hour's spent, I'll be your wife:
Shall I use flattery to my dearest heart?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: I'll hire a Parson, you prodigious heap of vertues, and meet you sooner then I would Elyzium delights.
