sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Be swift, sweet Sir: for since it must be so,
I'll haste to Church, and dress me as I go.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: I am going to Paradise in a down Blanket.

div.stage: Enter four Clowns with a glove lugging.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: You lye you Cur, I see it.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Sir, I say, I see it first tho.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: You, guds Waukers, I came when it was welly hot within side, so I did, you fools.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: So did I, and I'll go carry it to my Lord Lonus.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: So do, it's warm still, and so it was, when we all see it first, Wan't it? then it must be his Sons Glove, and he must be somewhere hereabouts.

sp.speaker: First
sp.p: I'll carry it.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You shan't, you whelp, I will.

div.stage: Third takes it up; all take it from him.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: We'll teach you better manners then to steal: I dare swear it's Litus his glove.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: So I say, you may see it is a Lords glove mon, by the Ribonds, what dost talk of that?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: And he's within shot.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: I'll carry it to his Father and tell him so.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: If you don't say we all found it, I'll swinge you agood.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: You fool, would you trust him? I'll cudgel you faith, so I will, ha' you no more wit? we'll all carry it together, else he'll get the mony to himself.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You ha' more wit then us all.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: Shall's drink when we have done?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: All wheaters, my hony.

div.stage: Enter Beucer leading Sarah in Theles Apparel.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: My humour was fain'd, I'll counterfeit no longer, but be serious.

div.stage: Thele enters, and pulls off Sarath 's Love-hood: Beucer amazed.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Witchcraft, Witchcraft!

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: 'Tis so, 'tis so;
Negromancie vanish, no Negromancie.

sp.speaker: Winifred.
sp.p: It's so indeed, it's so my love, my chuck.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: I married her by the name of Thele Moron,
Hers is so, and I changed mine to make
Your Marriage firm, and you religious:
She hers from the beginning by design.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.p: It's just, my Lord and husband.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: 'Tis just, just Maiden, and I free remit
Your sacred wisdom that invented it.
Great powers above ordain'd it; and I yeild
I'm rightly serv'd, who soweth shall reap the field.
And now to you dear Mistriss, I forgive,
And more commend the plot that makes you live
My dearest wife, protesting to Apollo,
This chastest Marriage, chastly true to follow,
With purest love imbrace, I do repent
What's past, and pray our lives hence be content.

div.head: ACT. V.
SCEN. 2.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: MY Lord, between Berania and my Son
You know proceedings, bless 'um both together.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: A Devil Devil 'um, he has got my bond, so they have, I vow.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: To the purpose.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why, I vow, I think they did it a purpose.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: I mean, speak to the matter.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: So I do, I vow; it's a great matter I should be cheated so, so it is; but she shall have him, if she will, as I live, d'ye see? we'll talk by and by, I'll ha' new clothes to the Wedding, so I will.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: I'll finish quickly to that Gallery there.
Sir, whether should one prize a noble name
And vertuous, or the respect of a friend,
If both can't dwell together?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Loose not the first for worlds.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: Was ever any tryed like me?
One of them two I must, 'tis your concerns:
I'll dye guiltless of your hurt, my Lord:
Please you to hear me, take the saddest story
That ere was told, yet short I'll strive to speak it,
It requires privacie.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Madam, we go.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Well, we have done a great deal of business, let me see, we have, I vow; well, what then? if my Daughter have Children, I shall be a Grand-father, so I shall.

How d'ye Son-in-law? this is a damnable trouble, so it is, till it's
done; you'll make all the haste you can, d'ye see? I vow, I was never half so preteritory when I was a Batchelor; if you were Married, it would be over, would it not?

sp.speaker: Losan.
sp.l: Our meeting, my Lord, tells me 't was ordain'd
You should avoid: 'lass I can go no further;
I've so much breath as shall tell you the strangest.
Forgive me Skies, shall I be false, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Tell me why this sadness is upon you.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: I will: turn Rock to hear it, let's be close.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: To kill, or to be kill'd 's the largest scope
My injuries can give; though all the signs
Of Hell and Terror meet me, I'll go on,
And be as famous for my courage in't
As Nero for his tyranny: What boots
A man when dead, to be accounted good?
If his exploits be noted, though they have power
To give an ague at the relation of them,
And make men drop down dead with very fear,
To tell the most inhumane bloody murthers
They have committed; yet some stander by
Adores the Actor for the strangeness of 'um.
Dionysius is as much talkt on, as if
He had chang'd all Cicily to Alms-houses:
I'm in the custody of sin, it whirls me
With his byas, and I can't resist it;
As good proceed as draw back and be murthered:
Though I should be surpriz'd i'th' midst o'th' fact,
My name shall signifie a bloody act.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: Whence comes my ruine? he won't speak to me;
What Sorcerer has had to do with him?

div.stage: Enter Petus with his sword in his hand.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Oh racks of horror! could you finde no other
Subject to work upon, but my destruction?
Lidorus, where's the truth your flattering tongue
Would dress in pleasant painted skins of Serpents?
Supream Commanders, is my life alone
Odious, that under such a black dark Cloud
You would smother all my joys?

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: With grief, my Lord,
I tell you of your faults: love blinded you,
Else many a time you might a seen him coming
Softly to meet Berania alone;
When you appear'd, he slunk away; and still
It is his custom, try, and trust: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Fawning delusions, you have took your pride,
To build higher the imaginations of my triumph,
That they the greater downfal may receive:
If I revenge my self, I'm worst of all.
Tho his disloyal heart can smother up
Such treachery to me, I'll never prove
Guilty of so much wickedness to him.
But stay fond kindeness, what, shall I incline
To spare him his life, that seeks to take mine,
I am reduc'd to this untoward end,
Either to loose my honour, or loose my friend.
If this my comfort's gone, that to forego,
Makes me ingrateful, and a Traytor too:
He gave it first, and who better then he
May borrow that which himself lent to me?
In this quandary make thy self a sheath:
Farewel once Mistriss, I must bid adieu
To my own self, but first of all to you;
When I am dead, that you may know the truth,
My blood shall be the pen and writer both:
Though you to others kindness could impart,
Yet your name onely's graven within my heart:
If ask'd, what did this tragedy incur,
You've been the cause, but I the Murtherer.
Throw fury on it self.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: For Heavens sake, my Lord, tell me the cause.

div.stage: Lidorus enters; seeing Petus, walks away.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: 'Tis true, ye darts of Pluto nail me here.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: Good Sir, speak.
'Tis too much to bear; he has been my friend,
Well, but now he is my foe; and I as justly
May make my self his, my sword shall reward it.

div.stage: Losana and Litus in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: How now, what think you?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: To write an invitation to Lidorus.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Then one or both; Lidorus has the best judgement.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: I know't, my Lord, tother's sooner dispatcht;
He has no skill at all, he dyes, my life for't.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: 'Tis well contriv'd, thanks to your wit and will.

div.stage: Enter Petus with a letter and Page.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Deliver this to Lord Lidorus; flee.

div.stage: Page meets Lidorus, he reads it.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Upon suspition, my Lord, where's the Wisdom
And sobriety was moderator
In all your passion? quite forgot? tho he
Be frenzied with an Amorous fire, I'll
Not take it as a challenge: Yet consider,
He's in earnest; if I don't accept it,
A woman or a coward nick-names me.
In Challenges, we ought more to reflect
On honours splendor, then the fight's neglect;
And invitations warlike, ought to be
Answer'd with courage, not benignity.
Tell him I stay: how clear am I from it?
Sweet is a life retir'd from all affairs
Of State or Court; one sad mischance or other
Waits upon Pomp; 't has always emulation
To study ones own private houshold-good,
In the short walks of an inclosed Garden;
And there content strikes envy in the bosome.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: My life or his, this treason must redeem:
Honor then friendship should have more esteem.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Sir.—

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Hold, your villany's too obvious to admit of ceremonious parles.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Charge.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Defend.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: End it.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Dispatch in justice.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: One thing I crave before I dye; tell me
The reason of this fight.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: By your life that sees his last period, resolve
The truth to what I ask.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Else Heavens shew themselves my everlasting enemies.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Hast not betray'd me? tell your unjust dealing.
With Berania, you are both dishonest.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Some miracle of the Gods shew my innocence:
Or if I have been guilty, all the torments
In Hell torment me for disloyalty.
Who blowed this fire in your brest, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Will't make me kill my self? is it not true?
Losana told me, and I see it too.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: What did you see?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: You walk away as soon
As entred; 'twas because we were together:
She must be alone to entertain your visits.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Losona told me, you suspected me
Of being too familiar with your Mistress;
Advised me to march off when I beheld
Berania with you, that in time it might
Abate your jealousie.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Your coming was upon a match, what say you?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: If so, let me be match'd with the worst fury
That ever howl'd in Hell: Losana bid me
Come to meet her here about some business:
I went when I see you, you know the cause.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: I smell sulphur; Losana told me
What I have spoke, and that you were lov'd of her.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Trayterous Losana, she-Devil, she 'twas, she
Brought me to my grave; secure her, I am faint;
The house is full of treason, use your judgement
To punish it; I could divulge it now,
But I want breath: I am sent for, Sir, farewel;
Your innocent servant remits you his death:
Once more farewel, and think upon me.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: My Lord, what's this?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Speak woman, did'st thou think
He'd a dyed with a heavy conscience, and
Conceal'd your sin to damn him?

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: I'll be tryed with fire, and in my defence
Kiss glowing steel: bring burning coles to me,
I'll keep 'um in my hand till they extinguish,
And never cry, to shew you I am clear,
Believe me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Did not you and Lidorus 'gree to meet?
He was a coming, but seeing me with you, return'd.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: My Sister bid me come about some business;
I thought not to meet you, and much less him.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: It's clear a plot to make us fight; tells him
That I suspected he was too familiar
With Berania: then tells me, that he
Was naught with her indeed; and more, that he
Agreed to meet her, but to walk away
At any time, when he see her with me;
Then bids him walk away, when he see me,
That it might in time abate my Jealousie,
And so got's all together here unknown
To each other; a cast a contrived Devilry:
He went away, for fear of my displeasure;
And I thought he went guilty of what was told me;
That we were both innocent, and both suspitious.

sp.speaker: Beran.
sp.p: Litus contrives it, my Maid once or twice see 'um together.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Desperate Losana, could the Devil invent
To cloak thy damn'd malice with this pretence
Of love to us both?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Lidorus is dead, it's known you kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Justice, suffer not
A wretch to tread the earth: Villanous woman,
Wert here, I'd gore thy hellish heart. O Monster!
Treacherous Monster; no less then thy infernal
Life shall satisfie me. Dear Lidorus,
How dare I name thee? every noise I hear
Crokes horror to me: why, I could not help it,
He can't be brought to life again: I'll dye,
And punish my self for so damn'd a sin.
Losana, Tiger-bitch, to thy breath
My hands inrag'd shall give a mournful death:
And for your witch-craft, I will make thee rue it
By just revenge, if my lifes price can do it.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: Hereabouts 'twas done; Petus is fled.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: He's gone, the King must pardon him, or we shall see him no more: what was it about?

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: They talk of treachy i'th' business.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Let's return.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: Good morrow my Masters all, good morrow.

div.stage: Enter King, Guard, and Marus, and Chancellor.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: May it please your Majesty, it's I am—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why you know it is against our Act that Duels should be fought, the penaltie's death.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: I come not to know rigor, but crave pardon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: To pardon this, would against Justice tend.

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.p: Justice draws mercy, Sir, at every end.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Yea, where the offence is done against the will.

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.p: It was my Liege, he did not love to kill.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why fought he then?

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.p: To vindicate his right.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: That's got by Law, and not by single might.

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.l: 'T was, Sir, so sudden done, forc'd by a plot,
That strength must needs decide, what Law could not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Fathers service, and the Sons deport;
One in our Wars, the tother in our Court,
Tho against my Law, command me to asswage
For once the penance of my Statutes rage;
But take notice, lest it should authorize
Others like manner precepts to despise,
Renew its force; and hence will hardly I
Give him his life that makes another dye.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Your pardon,
But let it teach better things.

div.stage: Litus and Losana in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: I knew it would not take, Lidorus is dead.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: I wish it had been Petus.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Wishes nothing avail, our treason's divulg'd; and
If we are caught, we shall soundly suffer.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: My disgrace is so great, I dare not return:
But since 'tis so, I'll alter our design,
And have his life, or it shall cost me mine.

div.stage: Enter Petus in a Night-gown, and Berania.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: A pardon? it were better that I were
Condemn'd to death, by the most cruel torture:
To live, is onely to be knawed upon,
And suffer lingrings, which subtly beguile
Me of my rest: One blow consumes them all;
But on my life depends a dearer; and
If I were dead, she'd be expos'd to th' rage
Of bloudy butcheries: I'll be reveng'd.
Dear Lidorus, how shall I pacifie
Thy angry Ghost! I kill'd thee, and were serv'd
But just, if thy deathy fingers should
Pull out my timorous heart.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: You see, my Lord,
The fruits of too rash anger.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Would I had,
Dear Madam, so sudden a Burial; let me
Sacrifice my life to asswage this fault,
In doubting of your chastity.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: Hold, my Lord, I shall dye to see you thus;
'T was foul, but now it's over.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Oh that I could come at this demons urchin!
I'd break the charms of Belzebub, and bite
The sulphry links that keep her; all the flashes
Of brimstone should but heat my purposes,
Till with her blood I had made a deadly poyson
Should kill all that but speak or think upon her:
Where art Air? cover her not, she will infect thee:
Ground swallow her up, or throw her to me, that I
May rid the world of lust and treachery.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: You see how things fall out.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: It is reported
You are sled; Petus beside himself,
Studies to make a sad example of you.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Are you against me too?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Not I, I wish
I could but see the colour of his heart-blood;
Till then I shant be quiet, nor you peel off
Perpetual shame.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Does he tear at me thus?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: I heard him in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: Enough,
I'll do his business: stay here, I have provided.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: I wish I had ne'er begun this, I am vext;
I dream of Blood and War: in my condition
Distraction banquets: I have entred on it,
And will go on.
But this one way to save our lives, go up,

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Here, here, come hither.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We attend your will.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: There's one has done me a great deal of wrong,
'Twill do no good to name it; if you will
Undertake to murder him, you shall
Be satisfied largely.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: No fear Madam, we can do it.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: I, and we will do it.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Where's the man?

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: Stand in that corner; within a little while he comes to you Gentlemen, be sure you kill him; I can't describe him by his clothes, but there none comes in a whole year; dispatch him quickly.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: We'll use swords to't.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Best we have them ready.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Surest and safest, these (All draw) will give him a meal he shall never disgest, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Go, and don't fail to kill the first that comes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We will, faith.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Go to Lord Petus, and tell him you saw Losana go down that lane just now; do your arrand well, and here's for you; then out by my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I was a coming to you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I heard you inquire for Madan Losana,
And I see her go down that lane just now.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Good Boy.
Now pitty be gone.

div.stage: He goes apace: draws his sword.
Four Clowns overtake him with clubs, and surprize him, taking him for Litus.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: Ha, ha, now we ha' you; nay, go to your Father.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: What mean you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Gentleman us no more then we Gentleman you; for I'faith you shall go.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Hold fast there: you are an undutiful son indeed; we'll Litus you, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: So, I thought we should catch you at last.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Stand off, you rustick Bores.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hold him fast; if we let him go, we shall all be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Get you home, we have searched the woods for you to some purpose.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: How dare you Villains?

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: Uds waukers, we'll cudgel you, so we will, for all you're a Lord.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: There's a good one, shall we please your father or you?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Swinge him, swinge him agood if he won't go; the King man set us a work to look you, and gave us leave.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Was ever Noble scratch'd with dogs before?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: In with him, in with him to his father; come along, good my Lord Litus, come along, or we'll make you with a murrin.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: It must be Litus man, and nobody else.

div.stage: Litus and Losana in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: Now Sir, from an abyss of discontent
Three thrusts have built us up security;
Peace over all those mists that interpos'd
Between Berania and you are vanish'd.
Petus is dead, the Boy came to my Chamber,
And see him run to eternal banishment:
Them three dispatcht him, ere one cry could come
Toth' ears of any living. Court your Mistriss;
But make devotion to me; I invented
His death, and your felicity.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Rare Madam!
Seeing there's no lets to my preferment, I'll
Adore your memory, and gratifie
With forty Duckets, them that laid him dead:
Come along Madam, I'll see how they sped.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: They could not finde resistance from him.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: I'm ravish'd with these Musical words,
I'll see how they did their business, and
Content 'um for it.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Well enough, I warrant you.

div.stage: Litus goes to the stage, and to the Thieves.
Thieves set on him, follow him out and fight.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Hold, I am not the man.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He is dispatcht.

div.stage: They kill him, and stop his mouth with an Hankerchaer. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Take me for Litus? Oh I fear she's gone.
Ho, ho; Watch, Watch, what's this? what bloudy business?

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: How came this, do you know, my Lord? I dare not but ask you.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Coming by and seeing it, made me cry out.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.l: Alack, he is newly kill'd;
Watch, go pursue the murderers: Alas, my Lord,
This is my Lord Lonus his son Litus, for whom
We have search'd so long.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: I was subdu'd, and carried to his father
Instead of him, not twenty minutes ago:
Curst be the foolish messengers for't.

div.stage: Enter Watch with one of the Murtherers.

sp.speaker: Murtherer.
sp.p: O be gratious, good my Lord, I'll confess all.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: To the Justice with him.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: We caught him by himself, just at the gate.

div.stage: Exeunt all, and carry the body.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Oh my son! could I not see him ere he dyed?

sp.speaker: Nymph.
sp.l: Now all's fulfill'd, that I
Did with my Sister prophesie.

p.hi: It is, it is, it is.

sp.speaker: Nymph.
sp.l: Their days shall increase
In kindness, love and peace.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Yea, yea, yea.

sp.speaker: Nymph.
sp.l: Till the terms of their breath.
Shall be ended by death.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: Now the Season draws nigh,
That we welcome our Bride;
With our Songs Melody,
When all grief's laid aside.

div.stage: Enter Petus, Marus, Berania and Hacca.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: For thee.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: The Crocodel confest it was:
But by kinde providence those Clowns ordain'd
To stop me by mistake, I should ha' perish'd.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Is my father so long a getting my Sister clear?

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: You have run through tryals.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: This was the most horrid,
Take all the story at a fitter time.

div.stage: Enter Occus and Losana distracted in a Night-gown.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: O come in my Daughter, Losana doth almost despair, so she does; she is forgiven, so she is, and at liberty, I vow, come in.

div.stage: Petus offers to run at her; Berania holds him.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: She is penitent.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: Here they come, I won't go to the Justices, I shall be burnt, keep me; there's Lidorus his Ghost.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: What ails her?

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.p: I'll go to bed; the man in the white cap; the dead man bound under the chin; the great Devils, and the little Devils twitch, and twitch off all the clothes: Look the dead horse heads chop, and chop in the sea, and the water all over my chamber: O dear, help, help, a cave in the Wet-wood; the Fryars and the Nuns that are dead, look how they run by me: Now, now again, there's the spirit with the withered face stands boult upright: d'ye see the little beads tumble about? tingle, tingle, tingle, that's the bell in the Monastery: Through the grates, the woman in Pautado, is hang'd without her head, for saying her prayers: Here comes the Devil like a mourning Gentlewoman with a peak: The Candles burn dim.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Hold, hold, what shall I do? here's nobody, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: In the name of all the Powers be silent.

div.stage: She falls down in a swound, they recover her; kneeling.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: Oh I'm undone! what ails me terror? I'm dead, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Sister, you have offended grievously.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: I am, tho griev'd, not sham'd to ask pardon
For that which will defile good lips to utter;
Caus'd by my envy to my Sister dear:
Envy, damn'd envy, makes me kneeling here.
The Devil and Litus urg'd me with their tongues
To cause my Sisters and your death at once:
Which sinful thought with grief I now repent,
To Litus vile, that I should so consent.
All men, me seem'd, did onely well affect
My virtuous Sister, and my self neglect:
That prompted me to this revengeful spight,
Fit to be nam'd in Charon's dismal night.
I'm justly serv'd, and Heavens just Judge hath brought
My wicked purpose to this wicked nought;
And made that evil light on my own head,
With which I hop'd you would be ruined.
Oh pardon me, and I'll henceforward be
Your humble Hand-maid in captivity.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Rise Losana, I forgive you
Your basest Treason, and henceforward wish
That better graces may your Brest inrich:
Your freest freedom, I do not deny,
Do what you please.

sp.speaker: Beran.
sp.p: Dear Sister, so do I.

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: I repent all for a preparative
To order and Religon, if I may
Be worthy on't: I humbly beg your leave,
That my devotion may be fitted by
A pilgrimage to the Shrine of Loretto;
By a new favour I may be absolv'd,
As penitent for all the impious stains
Of my bad life.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: I grant you your petition;
Go, if I never see you any more,
Labour to expoliate these sins
By earnest penitence: live holy,
And the everlasting goodness be your guide.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: If we ne'er see more, adieu, dear Sister,
I wish you all the sweetest contents of
Your strict and holy being.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Well, dear hony, God b'w'y, I weep to part, so I do: you had best take some Strong-water with you, I vow, so I do, to cheer you up in your long Journey, d'ye see?

sp.speaker: Losana.
sp.l: That ere we see if this be the last day,
Do you for me, as I for you will pray.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Adieu.

div.stage: Petus takes Berania by the hand.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Now what remains, but after all our fears,
Griefs, sorrows, troubles, terrors, frights and tears,
We beg.—

div.stage: Enter Messenger, gives Petus a Letter.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Make me not miserable again;
Or is it true? speak, can Lidorus live?

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: Read the just cause of his being secret.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Stars,
That of a man have made me an Angel;
Or happier, if't be true; don't tantalize me.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: My Master fearing your displeasure, vow'd
I'th' Holy Temple to see you bestow'd
On that fair Lady, or see his Winding-sheet
Laid at his head, ere you should know he liv'd;
But now rejoyces at your welfare.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Where remains the crown of all our sweetness?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Here, if you are resolv'd to call it so.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Forgive me, or punish, I am at your mercy.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Rise, and be as happy in your Mistriss,
As I in seeing you: my wounds, though deep,
Were cured on this condition.—

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: For offering him a thrust, my eyes have since
I've been recovered, paid the private walls
A thousand tears.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Let this bright day be worship'd:
A universal benefit lives with you.
The King has got his thoughts clad all in black
For your supposed loss; chang'd to ambition
My son, but you to make him glorious.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: It vext me to the heart to hear you were kill'd, so it did.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Don't let me hinder your proceedings, crown your expectation, my felicity.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Your hands; I joyn you both, you're man and wife.
The Ceremonies take another time.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: And so say I, I vow: but hark, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Hymen.
sp.l: WIth Joy and delight
We'll fill up the night;
That your marriage should be ended,
This dance we intended.
Minerva and the Gods,
When you first were at ods,
Did order this sporting
For your innocent courting.
Then happen what will,
We'll of mirth have our fill:
Your tears were our askers;
Look here come the Masquers.

div.stage: Descend three Goddesses, two Gods, one singing.

sp.l: Hymen and all the Gods above
That on this Wedding kindly smile:
Grant your blessings, and your love,
Envy and mischief to remove,
Peace and plenty all the while.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: We grant it all, it shall be so:
The Stars our bounty, and our will shall know.
Your nuptial pleasures shall abide
So long as love your hearts inflames;
Neer to cease for time or tide,
In joy your days shall swiftly glide;
With honour we'll ingross your names.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: We grant it all, it shall be so:
The Stars our bounty, and our wills shall know.

sp.speaker: Other God.
sp.l: Live like our selves, may every hour renew
Triumphs for constancy; Garlands for you
Shall be prepared rich, to make you prove
Shining below, as we are bright above:
Till then our Dance and Banquet shall display
The pleasure we have in this happy day.
Musick. All dance.
